audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a serious male voice announcing that Mister Millennium 7 is malfunctioning, and therefore they will take over the channel to discuss AESA radars. He adds that due to M7's "very human attitude toward technology", the speaker will address several issues that plague AESA radars. This is followed by a cheerful male voice interjecting that he is still here. The audio transitions to music in an electronic style, which then fades out as the cheerful male voice begins discussing the recent video on AESA radars inspired by news of the F-35 getting a new radar. He discusses how AESA technology has made everything else obsolete but then introduces the idea that the technology is not fully mature, so he wishes to point out the problems. He concludes by stating they will take a journey to understand the drawbacks and don'ts of the technology, with some of the material not covered on YouTube. Abruptly, sounds of static and a high-pitched noise like a jet engine abruptly drown out the speech. Then the cheerful male voice repeats the question "So, what is an AESA radar?".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that a radar uses multiple transmitter receiver modules instead of a single antenna. He goes on to describe that the antenna is made of smaller elements, each with a transmitter receiver module, noting the digital nature of the modules and the signal processing. The audio clip concludes.

The clip features one male speaker discussing the advantages of a particular solution, referencing benefits like "sensitivity, gain, signal to noise ratio," and emphasizing its "versatility" for military applications. He contrasts "a passive radar" with "a conventional radar," mentioning additional capabilities such as "communication, jamming, or passive listening." He then states that "pretty much everything else is obsolete," referring to radars used in combat. The speech is delivered in a clear and informative tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing radars and their capabilities, mentioning that they are sometimes called "multifunction arrays," and questioning the cost of having those capabilities. His tone is informative and slightly inquisitive. A sudden, loud sound effect resembling a "whoosh" or rushing air interrupts the speech abruptly. The clip returns to the speaker, who continues his discussion by pointing out complexity and cost.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing AESA radar. He highlights the "magnitude more complex" nature compared to conventional radar, mentioning that complexity contributes to design time and costs. The speaker is speaking in a factual, somewhat technical tone, explaining that AESA technology relies on gallium arsenide and gallium nitride circuits. He points out the high costs associated with these technologies and the decades required for their development. He states that non-standard production processes are needed, and "all these costs compound together." A brief throat clearing sound is heard at the end of the clip.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the challenges of cooling an active electronically scanned array radar, mentioning "active components", their density, and the heat they produce. He emphasizes the need for liquid cooling systems and the weight they add, and touches on gallium nitride as a potentially more energy-efficient technology. This is followed by the sound of jet engine, which remains consistent throughout the rest of the clip. Overlapping the jet engine sound is another sound effect: an electronic swoosh or whirring.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining the necessity of processing power for an "ISA radar" and the price one pays for its versatility. He notes current hardware and software limitations. He expresses a desire to do as much as possible in the digital domain, suggesting it simplifies things. Throughout the segment, the speaker maintains a factual and informative tone.

The clip features one male speaker in an informative tone, discussing radar upgrades and digital architecture limitations, which may lead to the use of analog components and the limitations associated with them. He notes that radars in service today may contain some analog components.

The clip features a single, male speaker who describes an ideal radar system, focusing on the components of the TR module such as wave form generation, digital-to-analog converter, power amplifier, antenna, and the subsequent receiving chain. His tone is informative and professional. He mentions the signal being sent downstream for processing and digital control by a central processor.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing technical aspects, mentioning "very high speed components" and expressing concern about cost or availability of technology, especially in relation to frequency. His tone is informative and slightly concerned.

The audio begins with someone discussing radars operating at lower frequencies like ground surveillance, including AWACS radars and S-band radars. The speaker has a clear, informational tone, explaining how these radars can utilize entirely digital AESA technology. They transition to discussing fighter radars operating at higher X-band and Ku-band frequencies and how these may require some analog components, especially in the beam-forming parts. The speaker mentions TR modules are managed in groups or channels, controlled digitally with digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital converters. There is a single speaker, and it sounds like a man.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing "hybrid solutions" and their typical use in "naval radars" with a professional and informative tone. This is followed by a sequence of electronic sounds, possibly related to the radar technology he mentioned. Next, the male speaker resumes, pointing out another typical drawback: "the scan loss," which he explains as "the loss that happens because the beam is moving through the target."

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker explaining how radars normally send more than one pulse toward a target, emphasizing that the received signal is summed to increase gain. He then discusses how the received signal can be lower if the target is off-axis, and that radars suffer from scan loss. He concludes that if a radar uses the beam by moving it continuously, it suffers from scan loss as well.

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing AESA radars and their issues. He explains that interference between modules limits the maximum deflection of the beam in an AESA antenna, and that the sensitivity of the antenna declines quickly with deflection. He states as a rule of thumb that the sensitivity advantage of an AESA array is gone with a deflection of 45 degrees. He concludes by explaining that this is why AESA arrays proliferate on aircraft like the Sukhoi 57 or mounted on repositioners like the Gripen, and notes that mechanically scanned antennas don't have this issue. He asks the listener if they see the point.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the "plenty of advantages" and some "relatively important disadvantages" of a subject, followed by a question if it's "actually worth it". He answers affirmatively based on its diffusion, noting he will mention the problems since others don't. The speaker concludes by stating that the advantages outweigh the disadvantages. As he mentions viewers can watch another video for details, calm and upbeat music begins to play. The music is instrumental, sounds electronic and smooth, suggesting a positive mood for the outro, as the speaker thanks the listener.
